Adele,

It's certainly not necessary to understand the entire SharpNEAT fra=
mework's
implementation. You simply need to understand the top-level API, w=
hich is
what I tried to explain in part 1 of the tutorial (
http://www.nash=
coding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-pa=
rt-1/).
I'm not sure what other advice I could give there.

The best thing =
to do is probably to just dive in. Start implementing your
project and then=
 if you can't figure out something specific, like your
project isn't compil=
ing or the results hint at a bug, then ask the group
here again.

Wesley

O=

te:

>
>
> Wesley,
> I took a look your tutorials before, They are hel=
pful, but for
> understanding them,  I know I should get more experience wi=
th C#, and Now,
> I am doing it.
> I want to use NEAT for implementing my g=
ame project, would you please help
> me? which parts of NEAT are more impor=
tant? which classes or libraries
> should I refer to study first? Is there =
some order to learning? Is it
> necessary to learn all of SharpNEAT classes=
 and codes? and so on...
>
> regards
> Adele

AT for beginners
>

> I hope my tutorial series is helpful. I'm not sure t=
hat SharpNEAT is
> something a C# novice wants to dive into, to be honest. =
If you simply want
> to get a project of your own up and running, then foll=
owing the tutorials
> will certainly help you do that. If you're looking fo=
r more insight into
> how the NEAT algorithm itself is implemented, as it s=
ounds like Adele is,
> then I would really not recommend SharpNEAT.
>
> The=
 SharpNEAT framework is huge, the modularity of it can make it
> intimidati=
ng, and there are tons of low-level optimizations Colin has made
> that obs=
cure things. If you do not feel confident in C#, but you wish to
> implemen=
t/understand a C# version of NEAT, then my suggestion would be to
> first g=
et more experience with C#. It's a simple enough language that
> anyone wit=
h an OO background can pick it up quickly.
>
> As Drew mentioned, there are=
 implementations available in almost every
> language now, so if you're str=
ong in another language, it may be a better
> move to look at that version.=
 Ken has a list of different implementations
> available here: http://www.c=
s.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software
>
>
> Wesley
>

examples. I'm afraid I'm a lowly C/C++ coder, and don't know

lly about C#. I believe the SharpNEAT C# version is one of
> the more polis=
hed NEAT libraries.
>

ting here that might
> help:
>
> http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutor=
ial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/
>
> That might help a=
 bit. If you have problems with going through the C#

sion might help. From what I understand, python is

age. I'm not sure if they've released any code
> yet. There's also the Java=
 version.
>
> Sorry I wasn't more help. Good luck!
>
> -Drew

uru, but I don't think too

lementation now. I think

Adele,<div><br></div><div>It's certainly not necessary to understand th=
e entire SharpNEAT framework's implementation. You simply need to under=
stand the top-level API, which is what I tried to explain in part 1 of the =
tutorial (<a href=3D"http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving=
-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/">http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/0=
7/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/</a>). I&#39=
;m not sure what other advice I could give there.</div>
<div><br></div><div=
>The best thing to do is probably to just dive in. Start implementing your =
project and then if you can't figure out something specific, like your =
project isn't compiling or the results hint at a bug, then ask the grou=
p here again.</div>

<div><span>I want to use NEAT f=

    <div>
      
      
      <div>I hope my=
 tutorial series is helpful.=A0I'm not sure that SharpNEAT is something=
 a C# novice wants to dive into, to be honest. If you simply want to get a =
project of your own up and running, then following the tutorials will certa=
inly help you do that.=A0If you're looking for more insight into how th=
e NEAT algorithm itself is implemented, as it sounds like Adele is, then I =
would really not recommend SharpNEAT.=A0</div>
<div>
<br></div><div>The Sha=
rpNEAT framework is huge, the modularity of it can make it intimidating, an=
d there are tons of low-level optimizations Colin has made that obscure thi=
ngs.=A0If you do not feel confident in C#, but you wish to implement/unders=
tand a C# version of NEAT, then my suggestion would be to first get more ex=
perience with C#. It's a simple enough language that anyone with an OO =
background can pick it up quickly.<div>

<br></div><div>As Drew mentioned, =
there are implementations available in almost every language now, so if you=
're strong in another language, it may be a better move to look at that=
 version. Ken has a list of different implementations available here:=A0<a =
rel=3D"nofollow" href=3D"http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software" target=
=3D"_blank">http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software</a></div>

<div><br><=
/div><div><br></div><div>Wesley<br><div><div><br><div>On Wed, Dec 7, 2011 a=
t 8:11 AM, Drew Kirkpatrick <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a rel=3D"nofollow" href=
=3D"mailto:drew.kirkpatrick@..." target=3D"_blank">drew.kirkpatrick@g=
mail.com</a>></span> wrote:<br>

<blockquote style=3D"border-left:1px #c=
cc solid">Adele,<br>
<br>
Sorry for the confusion, I thought you were tryin=
g to find=A0more C++<br>
NEAT examples. I'm afraid I'm a lowly C/C+=
+ coder, and don't know<br>
anything really about C#. I believe the Sha=
rpNEAT C# version is one of<br>
the more polished NEAT libraries.<br>
<br>
=
There's a 3 part tutorial using the C# version starting here that might=
 help:<br>
<a rel=3D"nofollow" href=3D"http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17=
/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/" target=3D"_bla=
nk">http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-=
with-sharpneat-2-part-1/</a><br>


<br>
That might help a bit. If you have =
problems with going through the C#<br>
code, the python version might help.=
 From what I understand, python is<br>
a very intuitive language. I'm n=
ot sure if they've released any code<br>
yet. There's also the Java=
 version.<br>
<br>
Sorry I wasn't more help. Good luck!<br>
<br>
-Drew<=
br>

&=
gt; I also started off from Mat Buckland's book, and have been working =
with a modified version of his implementation. If you're particular abo=
ut sticking with his implementation and C++ (his is a relatively simple imp=
lementation of NEAT from what I understand) I can send you my code if you w=
ant (buggy work in progress).<br>


><br>
> It's not a simple exa=
mple at all (competitive coevolution), but it would give you some code exam=
ples and bug fixes to Mat Buckland's original implementation (mine is a=
 Linux port). Probably only useful to you for looking at the changes I made=
 to Mr. Buckland's code, but that would be easy as most of the code is =
the same, and the classes retained their names from those described in his =
book.<br>


><br>
> You might want to start with getting his mineswee=
per (was that it?) example application running, and try putting in some of =
the bug fixes folks have recommended in his implementation (I think I can h=
elp find those). Once you have that working, you might want to try the XOR =
test, and perhaps pole balancing. I believe those are common tasks to under=
take.<br>


><br>
> Let me know if you want any code, or have any que=
stions I might be able to help with. I'm afraid I'm far from a NEAT=
 guru, but I don't think too many folks are working with Mat Buckland&#=
39;s implementation now. I think that's a great book, and that chapter =
helped me considerably in getting started working with NEAT.<br>


><br>=

><br>
> -Drew<br>
><br>
